string.u: Ask Yourself These Questions to Help Decide if You Should See a Mental Health Professional

resources.string: Some of the symptoms that you may find:
How well a person does depends on the cause of the mental illness.
If the cause can be corrected, the outlook is often good, and treatment with antipsychotic medication may be brief.
Some chronic conditions, such as schizophrenia, may need life-long treatment with antipsychotic medications to control symptoms.
Mental Illness can prevent people from functioning normally and caring for themselves. If the condition is left untreated, people can sometimes harm themselves or others.

string.name: tips_content_1_8
string.b: When to Contact a Medical Professional

resources.string: Call your Mental Health Professional if you or a member of your family is losing contact with reality. If there is any concern about safety, immediately take the person to the nearest emergency room to be seen by a doctor.

No matter what, even if there is not much bothering you, seeing a qualified mental health therapist can still be a good idea. However below are some questions to ask yourself, if you are in debate about considering Counselling:

• Illusions,
• No self-care,
• Irrelevant talks,
• Extreme anxiety,
• Abusive language, 
• Extreme depression,
• Over-sleep or insomnia,
• Problems with memory,
• Inability to make decisions, 
• Disorientation or confusion,
• Unusual behavior and dress,
• Excessive spending of money, 
• Extremely negative thoughts,
• Low self-esteem and confidence,
• No hygiene of self and environment, 
• Continuous physical and verbal abuse,
• Running away from home without informing,
• Speech or language that doesn't make sense, 
• Changes in eating or sleeping habits, energy level, or weight,
• Hallucinations: Hearing, seeing, or feeling things that are not there, 
• Disorganized thinking: Thoughts that "jump" between unrelated topics,
• Delusions: False beliefs that are not based in reality, especially unfounded fear or suspicion, 
• Other major signs where the person finds it difficult to function in his/her day to day life.

• Is your relationship in peril?
• Do you have loss of appetite?
• Are you feeling more frustrated?
• Do you have sleeping difficulties? 
• Has your weight drastically changed?
• Are you dealing with elderly parents?
• Are you exhibiting more signs of anger? 
• Are you feeling hopeless, or in despair?
• Do you find yourself worrying excessively?
• Do you have unexplained aches and pains? 
• Are you grieving for someone or even a pet?
• Have you ever experienced a traumatic event?
• Do you have feelings of isolation and loneliness? 
• Do you have less patience with people in your life?
• Are you abusing substances like alcohol and/or drugs?
• Do you find yourself feeling sad, and not being able to shake it? 
• Do you have trouble concentrating, or focusing on getting tasks done?
• Are you dealing with diffiulties in your relationship with your children? 
• Do you feel more stressed, or are there things going on that are stressful to you?
• Are there changes in behavior in your mate or other close family members that are bothering you?
